author: By Hannah Beech, Muktita Suhartono and Dera Menra Sijabat
title: Debris From Indonesian Submarine Is Found, Dimming Hopes of Rescue
description: Search teams from several countries had been looking for the navy vessel, which sank near Bali with 53 people aboard.
content: There are few bonds stronger than that of sailors on a submarine. Each person selected for the crew must fulfill a critical role in an intricate interplay that allows a small metal vessel to dive deep in the sea for weeks at a time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda M. Fairbanks
title: Frigid Waters: A Fleeting Balm for a Mother’s Unspeakable Grief
description: To shake up the tedium of quarantine, I started doing polar plunges with Stephanie Reece, who was driven by something else entirely.
content: By January, we were 10 months into the pandemic and I couldn’t remember the last time I had left Long Island. My husband and I were raising two young children and working, cleaning and cooking, indefinitely, from home. It was hard to imagine a time when I had felt more claustrophobic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 7 Deputies Placed on Leave After Fatal Shooting of Black Man in North Carolina
description: Gov. Roy Cooper on Friday joined growing calls for the release of body-camera footage of the fatal shooting of Andrew Brown Jr. in Elizabeth City.
content: Seven sheriff’s deputies have been placed on leave, and the governor of North Carolina is calling for the release of body-camera footage after deputies shot and killed a Black man on Wednesday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Can Polyamory With a Monogamous Partner Work?
description: And: The gift of love and a heart.
content: Navigating the nuances of an intimate relationship can be complicated, especially if one partner identifies as polyamorous and the other partner identifies as monogamous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alana Paterson and Julie Creswell
title: There Is a Lot of Fungus Among Us
description: Coffee for immune support. Supplements for inflammation. And psychedelics promising relief from serious ailments. Mushrooms are everywhere, and investors are paying attention.
content: Inside a state-of-the-art lab, tucked in an industrial neighborhood on Vancouver Island in British Columbia, employees wearing protective suits move around two clear boxes, careful not to disrupt the tubes and sensors that keep temperature and humidity constant. Inside the boxes are mushrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: So Anthony Fauci Isn’t Perfect. He’s Closer Than Most of Us.
description: We owe him gratitude, not grief.
content: The phrases “public servant” and “public service” are exhausted to the point of meaninglessness. They’re tics. They roll off politicians’ tongues as readily as requests for money, suggesting that adulation and power aren’t the more potent draws to elected office. They’re invoked in regard to other government workers, as if decent paychecks and generous pensions weren’t a significant lure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: The Anguish of the World’s Doctor
description: Dr. Tedros of the W.H.O. publicly focuses on managing the pandemic. Privately, he weeps as his Tigrayan people are raped, starved and slaughtered.
content: He is the world’s doctor, and for months he has tirelessly led the global response to the coronavirus pandemic while privately nursing a piercing anguish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kulish
title: MacKenzie Scott Gave Away Billions. The Scam Artists Followed.
description: She has no large foundation, headquarters or public website. That makes it easier to dispense money on her own terms — and for others to prey on the vulnerable in her name.
content: Danielle Churchill needed help. She was raising five children in Wollongong, on the Australian coast south of Sydney, and had to cover thousands of dollars in special therapy fees for her 10-year-old son, Lachlan, who has autism. She tried crowdfunding on the site GoFundMe, but raised just a tiny fraction of what she had hoped for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: ‘It’s More Than Just Tragic’: Ma’Khia Bryant and the Burden of Black Girlhood
description: The fatal shooting of a 16-year-old in Columbus, Ohio, highlights the different standards that young Black girls are held to.
content: — Brittany Cooper, the author of “Eloquent Rage”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Terrorism Fears Feed the Rise of France’s Extreme Right
description: The far-right leader Marine Le Pen called for “hundreds of thousands of illegals” to be deported. Her message resonates after the fatal stabbing of a police officer on Friday.
content: PARIS — “Marine Le Pen does not have to say anything,” said Alain Frachon, a former editor of the French daily Le Monde. “Each time France is hit by terrorism, the extreme right benefits.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: C.E.O. Pay Remains Stratospheric, Even at Companies Battered by Pandemic
description: While millions of people struggled to make ends meet, many of the companies hit hardest in 2020 showered their executives with riches.
content: Boeing had a historically bad 2020. Its 737 Max was grounded for most of the year after two deadly crashes, the pandemic decimated its business, and the company announced plans to lay off 30,000 workers and reported a $12 billion loss. Nonetheless, its chief executive, David Calhoun, was rewarded with some $21.1 million in compensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: In N.Y.C. Jail System, Guards Often Lie About Excessive Force
description: More than half of the roughly 270 correction officers disciplined over a 20-month period lied to investigators or filed incomplete or inaccurate reports.
content: One New York City Correction officer struck a jailed person in the face for no legitimate reason. Another put a detainee in a banned chokehold several times. A third failed to stop subordinates from using unnecessary force, according to newly released discipline records.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Halting the Vast Release of Methane Is Critical for Climate, U.N. Says
description: A major United Nations report will declare that slashing emissions of methane, the main component of natural gas, is far more vital than previously thought.
content: A landmark United Nations report is expected to declare that reducing emissions of methane, the main component of natural gas, will need to play a far more vital role in warding off the worst effects of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Let’s Launch a Moonshot for Meatless Meat
description: It wouldn’t actually take that much of an investment for Biden to get us headed in the right direction.
content: I’m a vegan, but I’m also a realist. There’s no chance humanity is going to give up meat, en masse, anytime soon. That said, we can’t just wish away the risks of industrial animal agriculture. If we don’t end this system, soon, terrible things will happen to us and to the planet. Terrible things are already happening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Elon Musk to Host ‘Saturday Night Live’
description: Musk, who runs Tesla and SpaceX, will become the rare “S.N.L.” host not from the worlds of entertainment, politics or sports.
content: There have been some unexpected “Saturday Night Live” hosts over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Voting Rights Standoff Stalls Trump-Inspired Ethics Measures
description: After the Trump presidency, democracy activists and many Democrats seized a moment to rebuild constitutional guardrails, but the effort could die in the face of a larger fight over voting rights.
content: WASHINGTON — After Donald J. Trump lost the election and was impeached for his role in the Capitol riot, democracy preservation groups pointed with urgency to what they called a last, best chance to address the holes in the Constitution exposed by his presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Women Are Battling China’s Angry Trolls. The Trolls Are Winning.
description: As online attacks against Chinese feminists intensify, popular social media companies are responding by removing the women — not the abusers — from their platforms.
content: The feminists’ social media accounts had been slowly disappearing in China for days. And when that wasn’t enough for their angry critics, a powerful voice on the internet stepped in to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Republicans Target Voter Access in Texas Cities, but Not Rural Areas
description: In Houston, election officials found creative ways to help a struggling and diverse work force vote in a pandemic. Record turnout resulted. Now the G.O.P. is targeting those very measures.
content: HOUSTON — Voting in the 2020 election presented Zoe Douglas with a difficult choice: As a therapist meeting with patients over Zoom late into the evening, she just wasn’t able to wrap up before polls closed during early voting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: I’m Buying a House. Can the Seller Really Take the Chandeliers?
description: In a typical sale, anything affixed to the walls, floors or ceilings stays with the house. But there’s always room for negotiation.
content: Q: After my offer on a Westchester house was accepted, my broker told me that the sellers wanted to keep the dining room chandelier and the bathroom sconces, and replace them with building-grade fixtures. This seems so strange. I thought fixtures were part of the house. I don’t want to lose this house over a couple of sconces and a chandelier, but packing them up and taking them away seems petty. What if the sellers decide they want to take more items out of the house before the closing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary D. Carter
title: The Woman Who Shattered the Myth of the Free Market
description: Joan Robinson upended the misogynistic good-old-boys’ network of economists and devised theories around competition and labor vital to the antitrust debates of today.
content: When Joan Robinson arrived at Cambridge University in 1929, nobody expected her to become one of the most important economists of the 20th century — let alone the 21st. She had spent the past three of her nearly 26 years in India, where she lived without professional responsibilities while her husband, Austin, an economist six years her senior, tutored a child maharajah. When Austin returned to Britain to join the Cambridge economics faculty, Joan, who had studied the subject as an undergraduate, felt her own ambitions kindled. But she had entered an environment hostile to women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Laverne Cox on the Red Carpet, Politics and What to Expect on Oscars Night
description: The actor and advocate thinks it’s time to make fashion statements.
content: Ever since she appeared at the Golden Globes via remote camera in a regal red gown by Thai Nguyen, because “we should have a fashion moment,” Laverne Cox has been a pioneer of the virtual red carpet. Here, she explains why she believes in the power of dressing up even in a pandemic — and why a statement gown can say be a lot more than just “glam.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Decades After Police Bombing, Philadelphians ‘Sickened’ by Handling of Victim’s Bones
description: The disclosure that anthropologists at two Ivy League universities had kept bones from a victim of the 1985 MOVE bombing infuriated its members as well as city leaders.
content: In the early evening of May 13, 1985, the police flew a helicopter over a crowded West Philadelphia neighborhood and dropped a bomb on the rowhouse where members of the communal, anti-government group MOVE lived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
title: Biden’s Bet on a Climate Transition Carries Big Risks
description: The president’s plans to cut emissions in half by 2030 relies heavily on a government effort to steer the development of new industries, but business leaders are fretting over the rapid timeline.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s pledge to cut America’s climate warming emissions in half by 2030 is technologically feasible and, scientists say, ecologically imperative. Economically, it could be a gamble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: When?
description: Kristian House and Mike Dockins nudge us on our weekend.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Solving this grid is like finessing a car out of a slippery spot. (If you’re a nondriving city person, it involves a lot of self-doubt, some ill-controlled acceleration, sudden stops and reversals.) I feel as if this is an apt comparison since there are, oh, 25 vehicular references in the clues today, or at least it felt that way at one point. There is also an absolute deluge of unusual trivia; I am here to tell you that I knew exactly one entry cold — ELOISE, natch — and I not only survived, but also found this solve ultimately very endearing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How to Navigate the Postpandemic Office
description: Many companies see the appeal of combining office life with work-from-home flexibility. How to strike the right balance can be less clear.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady, Julie Bosman and Noah Weiland
title: J.&.J. Vaccine Will Be Available Again Soon
description: U.S. experts weigh the risks for younger women and cases of a rare blood-clotting disorder, and lift the pause in giving the one-shot vaccine.
content: Use of the one-shot Johnson & Johnson Covid vaccine will resume within days, but with a warning added to its label about the risk for a rare blood-clotting disorder that has occurred among young women, the Food and Drug Administration announced on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franklin Leonard
title: Hollywood’s Anti-Black Bias Costs It $10 Billion a Year
description: If the industry won’t change on principle, it can at least change for the money. Reform would enrich people of color, and everyone else.
content: Days after a Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin, suffocated George Floyd and the video went viral, I watched my social media feed fill with blackout tiles and corporate publicity statements. They poured in from every industry, proclaiming solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement. Hollywood — where I have worked for almost two decades — was no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: After Fatal Shooting, North Carolina Sheriff Calls for Release of Video
description: A Black man was fatally wounded while the authorities were executing warrants. Law enforcement officials are under mounting public pressure.
content: Amid mounting public pressure, a North Carolina sheriff said on Saturday that he wants body-camera video made public after one of his deputies shot and killed a Black man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: N.Y.C. Bans Pesticides in Parks With Push From Unlikely Force: Children
description: “A bunch of kindergartners,” now in seventh grade, worked years to push the City Council to approve a ban on toxic pesticides in parks, playgrounds and other spaces.
content: Seven years ago, a kindergarten teacher at P.S. 290 in Manhattan was following her students’ curiosity about the origins of food when she led them in a role play on how toxic pesticides harm people, ecosystems and even — to the 5-year-olds’ horror — turtles like their class pet, Soccer Ball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bruder
title: What ‘Nomadland’ Exposes About Fear in America
description: People who live in homes-on-wheels should not have to be in constant fear of “the knock.”
content: Spending the first night in my 1995 GMC camper van, I lay awake for hours in my sleeping bag, watching the window shades glow — white, then red, over and over — as cars sped past in the dark. Is that one slowing down? I wondered. Can they see I’m in here? Will they call the cops?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Andrew Das
title: English Soccer Announces Social Media Boycott to Protest Online Abuse
description: The boycott, set to begin on Friday, is the most direct effort yet by a sport to pressure social media companies like Twitter, Instagram and Facebook to take action against abuse.
content: English soccer officials said Saturday that they would conduct a social media blackout next weekend to protest “the ongoing and sustained discriminatory abuse received online by players and many others connected to football.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Biden’s Sky-High Promises on Racial Justice
description: A president evolves on civil rights along with the country.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: Chauvin Was Convicted. Something Is Still Very Wrong.
description: What can be done about all of the suffering that remains?
content: After a wretched and withering year that didn’t so much pass by as scorch through, the guilty verdict in Derek Chauvin’s trial for the murder of George Floyd arrived as a relief. It’s been a long time since it felt as though Americans had the luxury of thinking about the future we want to live in, as opposed to putting out fires in an endless present. In so many respects, we were due for a little hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: The Short, Unhappy Life of Europe’s Super League
description: A timeline of the Super League, which was designed to reshape European soccer and instead rained only grief on its 12 clubs in the two days before it imploded.
content: The 48-hour history of European soccer’s long-discussed, hastily arranged, belatedly announced, much-derided and quickly abandoned Super League was short on chapters but long on drama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Troy Carter Elected to Congress From Louisiana
description: Mr. Carter, a state senator from New Orleans, defeated State Senator Karen Carter Peterson in a race to succeed former Representative Cedric Richmond, who left Congress to become an adviser to President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Michelson
title: How to Reserve a Campsite, Even at the Last Minute
description: Who says you can’t get a  reservation for the great outdoors this weekend?
content: Pretend it’s a Monday in midsummer. You live in or near a big city, a few hours from mountains or forests, and you want to go camping this coming weekend — a few days away. Before the pandemic, that may have been possible. But these days the outdoors and camping are having their biggest boom since humans lived in caves, and finding a last-minute campsite is about as hard as spotting wild glowing mushrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Thompson
title: Pet Project
description: In the graphic novel “Allergic,” a young girl is relentless in her quest for a furry friend.
content: ALLERGICWritten by Megan Wagner LloydIllustrated by Michelle Mee Nutter
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Generation X, Your AARP Card Awaits
description: The advocacy group for the over-50 set welcomes a mercurial generation that never wanted to grow up in the first place.
content: The skateboarder, wearing a flannel shirt and black sneakers, glides a board plastered with stickers toward a kick-turn in a sun-dappled concrete bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon bring us the forest; can we see the trees?
content: ACROSTIC — Arbor Day is April 30, and I guarantee the timing of this acrostic isn’t coincidental. The passage today is from a really wonderful recent book called “The Overstory,” which won the 2019 Pulitzer Prize in fiction. People who love words and intricate puzzly plots owe it to themselves to try some Richard Powers — I love “The Overstory,” “The Echo Makers” and “The Time of Our Singing,” but you truly can’t go wrong. If you want incredible nature writing with your words and puzzles, start with this book, and read some of it in the shade of a tree for enhancement.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Crisis in San Francisco as Fentanyl Deaths Soar
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 24, 2021.
content: “I can say for sure that what we are doing is not working and that it’s getting worse every single day.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The World Needs Many More Coronavirus Vaccines
description: Wealthy nations have to step up.
content: Low- and middle-income nations are facing an unconscionable shortage of coronavirus vaccines that threatens to upend progress against the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: In Poland, an L.G.B.T.Q. Migration As Homophobia Deepens
description: An escalation in verbal attacks by the Polish government, with the support of the Roman Catholic Church, as well as the threat of physical violence on the streets of many cities, has triggered an exodus of gay people.
content: For months, government ministers spewed vicious rhetoric about gay people. Trucks blasted anti-gay hate messages from loudspeakers on the streets of Poland’s cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: The Arms Merchant in the Sights of Russia’s Elite Assassination Squad
description: Russian spies have twice tried to poison Emilian Gebrev. Now, revelations in the Czech Republic show they also destroyed  shipments of his military supplies.
content: For a major arms merchant, Emilian Gebrev cuts the modest figure of a bemused grandfather, preferring soccer jerseys and polo shirts to suits and ties, driving his own car and insisting that he is of little importance outside his native Bulgaria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Africa’s already slow vaccine drive is threatened as supplies from a stricken India are halted.
description: India’s dire Covid crisis is having global ripple effects, especially in Africa, which has 17 percent of the world’s people but is far behind in vaccinations.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — The rapidly escalating coronavirus crisis in India is not only forcing hospitals to ration oxygen and sending families scrambling to find open beds for infected loved ones. It is also wreaking havoc on the global vaccination effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Egyptology Is Having a Big Moment. But Will Tourists Come?
description: Tourism in Egypt has been buffeted by political instability and terrorism. But the pandemic has dealt the industry its biggest blow in years.
content: CAIRO — On a cool morning last November, Egypt’s tourism and antiquities minister stood in a packed tent at the vast necropolis of Saqqara just outside Cairo to reveal the ancient site’s largest archaeological discovery of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Crushed Dream Factory
description: Craving escapism from the Oscar contenders that reflect our sad reality.
content: WASHINGTON — People are talking about the Oscars this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: DMX Remembered by Family, Friends and Fans: ‘He Saved My Life’
description: The memorial event at Barclays Center was closed to the public, but hundreds of fans congregated outside to honor the rapper’s life.
content: The day began the way that the man it was all for might have chosen to end it: with a prayer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Sameer Yasir, Hari Kumar, Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
title: As Covid-19 Devastates India, Deaths Go Undercounted
description: Fatalities have been overlooked or downplayed, understating the human toll of the country’s outbreak, which accounts for nearly half of all new cases in a global surge.
content: NEW DELHI — India’s coronavirus second wave is rapidly sliding into a devastating crisis, with hospitals unbearably full, oxygen supplies running low, desperate people dying in line waiting to see doctors — and mounting evidence that the actual death toll is far higher than officially reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: 4 Astronauts Float Into the International Space Station and Open Arms
description: The crew arrived on Saturday on the Dragon Endeavour, a spacecraft built by SpaceX, Elon Musk’s space exploration company.
content: “Endeavour arriving.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Recipes for Your Rotation
description: Add vegan tantanmen and roasted rhubarb cobbler to your weekend cooking plans.
content: Another week, another slate of fresh recipes from New York Times Cooking for you to cook. Some of our newest recipes were also among our most popular this week, like Melissa Clark’s sweet-tart roasted rhubarb cobbler, Yotam Ottolenghi’s cozy confit leeks with lentils, Sue Li’s showstopping fried fish sandwich and Hetty McKinnon’s hearty vegan tantanmen (above). Give any one of them a go this weekend, and we’ll bet what’s new now will soon feel like an old friend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hahna Yoon
title: ‘Minari’ Showcases Today’s South Korean Fashion
description: A trend called “newtro” is cool in Seoul.
content: The costumes in Minari, a film by Isaac Chung, include midcentury-style button-downs and slim dresses with straight, conservative lines. These looks from the 1970s and ’80s are part of a trend in present-day South Korea called “newtro” or new retro, which is seen in popular neighborhoods of Seoul like Hongdae and Euljiro; music videos like “Dynamite,” by BTS, and “Woowa,” by Dia; and television shows like “Mr. Sunshine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: U.S. Is Under Pressure to Release Vaccine Supplies as India Faces Deadly Surge
description: The Biden administration is blocking the export of supplies that Indian vaccine makers say they need to expand production.
content: Biden administration officials are coming under increasing pressure to lift restrictions on exports of supplies that vaccine makers in India say they need to expand production amid a devastating surge in Covid-19 deaths there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Anthony Edwards Will Dunk on You. And Beat You in Ping-Pong?
description: The Minnesota Timberwolves are not good this season. But Edwards, their rookie No. 1 draft pick? He is giving fans many reasons to watch (and listen).
content: As a senior at Holy Spirit Preparatory School in Atlanta, Anthony Edwards commuted about an hour each way from his home in the southern reaches of the city. In addition to the geographical distance, the challenge was that he had no reliable mode of transportation. So he would lean on friends, family members, neighbors and coaches to ferry him back and forth. They wanted to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chloe Malle
title: Have You Satisfied Your Covid Compliance Officer?
description: They’re at the Oscars, on film sets, at festivals and office buildings. Meet the new gatekeepers to gathering responsibly.
content: Dr. Linda Dahl was pacing the alleyway off a sound stage at Kaufman Astoria Studios in Long Island City. It was 7 a.m. on a gray April morning, and Dr. Dahl, an ear, nose and throat surgeon turned Covid compliance officer, was overseeing testing for the nearly 300-person cast and crew of a TV production. Already it had been a long day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Stretching Exercises
description: Ew, Jeremy Newton makes us work out.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is a visual grid that looks different online; if you want to see the print effect without spoiling anything, here’s a version. Jeremy Newton is the constructor (or drill/Pilates instructor) today. And since it’s my job, I looked in the xwordinfo archives and found some terrific and unusual Sundays from a decade ago under his byline — so if you’re not quite ready for the ice bath, you can run some more laps. Mr. Newton is a software engineer on mobile games, including Crosswords With Friends, Zynga Poker and Dragon Academy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Carlotta Gall
title: Breaking With Predecessors, Biden Declares Mass Killings of Armenians a Genocide
description: The Turkish government, as well as human rights activists and ethnic Armenians, had a muted response to the news, describing the move as largely symbolic.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Saturday recognized the mass killings of Armenians more than a century ago as genocide, signaling a willingness to test an increasingly frayed relationship with Turkey, long a key regional ally and an important partner within NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What Can Comic Book Heroes Teach Us About Black History?
description: A yearlong Narrative Projects series offers a fresh perspective on Black history, looking beyond the familiar lessons you may have learned in school.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Cara Buckley
title: Volatile and Vengeful: How Scott Rudin Wielded Power in Show Business
description: For decades, the producer has cultivated and castigated people at all levels of entertainment. Now his past is catching up with him.
content: Scott Rudin has long been one of the most celebrated and powerful producers in Hollywood and, especially, on Broadway — an EGOT who won an Emmy, a Grammy, an Oscar and 17 Tony Awards while developing a reputation as one of the vilest bosses in the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: General Who Led Myanmar’s Coup Joins Regional Talks on the Crisis
description: Southeast Asian leaders called for the killings to end. But critics feared Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing’s presence at the Indonesia talks would legitimize his rule.
content: The army general who has ruled Myanmar since leading the overthrow of its civilian government met on Saturday in Indonesia with leaders of other Southeast Asian nations who expressed concern about the army’s killing of hundreds of pro-democracy protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Column on ‘Wokeness’ Ruining Disney World Experience Draws Backlash
description: In a guest column for The Orlando Sentinel, a Disney fan said he was reconsidering his commitment to the park “because Disney cares more about politics than happy guests.”
content: A column complaining that Disney World’s “wokeness” is ruining the fun “because Disney cares more about politics than happy guests” drew a sharp backlash online this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: DeGrom Shuts Out the Nationals and Sets a Strikeout Record
description: The Mets’ ace has 50 strikeouts in four starts. The Yankees, meanwhile, won again thanks to Giancarlo Stanton.
content: Jacob deGrom struck out a career-high 15, pitched a two-hitter and boosted the sagging Mets’ offense with a go-ahead double from the No. 8 spot in the batting order, powering his team over the Washington Nationals, 6-0, Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein
title: What Doomed the Great City of Cahokia? Not Ecological Hubris, Study Says.
description: Excavations at the city, famous for its pre-Columbian mounds, challenge the idea that residents destroyed the city through wood clearing.
content: A thousand years ago, a city rose on the banks of the Mississippi River, near what eventually became the city of St. Louis. Sprawling over miles of rich farms, public plazas and earthen mounds, the city — known today as Cahokia — was a thriving hub of immigrants, lavish feasting and religious ceremony. At its peak in the 1100s, Cahokia housed 20,000 people, greater than contemporaneous Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Cain
title: When the Wedding Is Postponed, Renovate a House in Provence
description: For Parisians Rime Arodaky, a wedding gown designer, and Greg Finck, a photographer, picking a creative project gave them focus amid the many lockdowns in France.
content: During the initial coronavirus lockdown last year, Rime Arodaky, a wedding gown designer, and Greg Finck, a wedding photographer, spent six weeks in a friend’s country home in Provence, France. There they home-schooled their son, Andrea, 3, and Mr. Finck’s daughter from a previous marriage, Juliette, 9. They slowed down from their hectic life in Paris, where they jointly ran Ms. Arodaky’s namesake bridal gown company and Mr. Finck managed his wedding photography business. The Provence house was a refreshing escape from their two-bedroom apartment in Paris. They had country air, farm-to-table food, local wine, and plenty of tractors to excite their toddler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango, John Eligon and Shaila Dewan
title: How the Trial Over Floyd’s Death Flipped the Script for Black Victims
description: George Floyd was presented as a full person, not just a body beneath a police officer’s knee. Derek Chauvin, who was convicted in his murder, remained an aloof figure.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — “His name,” the prosecutor said, “was George Perry Floyd Jr.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Two Crises of Conservatism
description: The G.O.P. doesn’t know how to win majorities; the right doesn’t know what it’s conserving anymore.
content: For the last few months I’ve been one of the teachers for a Yale course entitled “The Crisis of Liberalism,” about recent challenges to the liberal order from populists and progressives, socialists and nationalists, the further left and right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Cuomo’s Approval Rating Has Fallen. He Could Still Win Re-Election.
description: Allegations of sexual harassment have hurt Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s favorability rating. But 57 percent of Democrats say he is doing a good job, a new poll shows, enough support to give him a decent chance at a fourth term.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has not had much good news over the past few months. His poll numbers have not been much of an exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Reveals Charges Against Outspoken Businessman
description: Sun Dawu, a rural tycoon who has been a thorn in the Communist Party’s side, was detained in November as the party moved to silence critics and keep the private sector in line.
content: Sun Dawu, an outspoken rural businessman who has been a thorn in the side of China’s ruling Communist Party, has been formally arrested on a number of charges, months after being taken into detention.
source.name: The New York Times

description: A 1934 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, an A-frame retreat in Lake Arrowhead and a traditional home in San Diego.

author: By Lucas Lilieholm and McKenzie Marshall
title: India Faces Record-Breaking Virus Surge
description: India set a global record for new daily coronavirus infections on Friday, beating the previous record from the day before, while oxygen supplies dwindled.
content: India set a global record for new daily coronavirus infections on Friday, beating the previous record from the day before, while oxygen supplies dwindled.

author: By Storyful
title: Monster Truck Carries Rapper DMX’s Coffin to Memorial Service
description: A procession of motorcycles followed a monster truck carrying DMX’s coffin from Yonkers, N.Y., to Brooklyn on Saturday ahead of a memorial at Barclays Center.

title: Corrections: April 24, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 24, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about President Biden’s commitment to halving U.S. climate emissions misspelled the given name of the French president. He is Emmanuel Macron, not Emanuel.
